p: Carposina cardinata is an important fruit borer of M. calvescens. Attacks of this lepidopteran can reduce seed fruit production. Studies have verified that herbivores of reproductive structures can be very effective weed biocontrol agents because they can reduce recruitment to the seedling stage of the populations ( Bellows and Headrick 1999). A similar Carposina, C. bullata Meyrick, was used as a biocontrol agent of C. hirta in Hawaii, where it established and became very effective. This species feeds internally in the flower buds and is specific to the Miconia and Clidemia and the damage to the flowers of C. hirta prevents seed production ( Nakahara et al. 1992). The major difficulty in the introduction of C. bullata was obtaining sufficient numbers of individuals to be released because no mass—rearing method was developed ( Culliney and Nagamine 2000). Here, we verified that C. cardinata could be reared in the laboratory during the fruiting period of M. calvescens and a great number of adults could be obtained. Another example of Carposina used in control of weed is the seed—moth, C. autologa introduced in South Africa to control a serious invasive plant Hakea sericea, a small tree Australian origin ( Gordon and Fourie 2011).
